title: Sepp Blatter to quit as Fifa president
desc: Sepp Blatter is to resign as president of football's governing body Fifa amid a corruption scandal after 17 years in charge.

title: 'Race against time' in China capsize
desc: Chinese rescuers are in a race against time to find survivors among hundreds of people missing in a capsized cruise ship on the Yangtze River.

title: Boko Haram leader not in new video
desc: Nigeria's militant Islamists release a new video without Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau appearing in it raising questions about his fate.

title: Greek PM in new debt deal proposal
desc: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras says he has issued a realistic proposal to its international creditors in an attempt to secure a deal over its debts.

title: Tributes paid to Charles Kennedy
desc: Colleagues friends and political adversaries pay tribute to former Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy after the 55-year old's sudden death.

title: German ex-leader 'in intensive care'
desc: Germany's former Chancellor Helmut Kohl is in intensive care after surgery on his intestine German media reports say.

title: Iraq coalition 'winning against IS'
desc: The US insists a coalition effort to halt the advances of Islamic State in Iraq is succeeding after ministers from 20 countries meet in Paris.

title: MH370 suit settled out of court
desc: Two Malaysian children who lost their father on flight MH370 have settled their negligence case with the airline and government out of court.

title: Eurozone returns to inflation
desc: The eurozone's inflation rate turned positive in May after five months of falls or stagnation reviving hopes of an economic recovery in Europe.

title: Boston police kill terror suspect
desc: Officials say the man attacked officers with a large knife after being approached by a Boston police officer and an FBI agent.

title: German singing star admits card scam
desc: Severino Seeger the newly-crowned winner of a German television singing contest appears in court and admits defrauding pensioners.

title: Redmayne to star in Potter spin-off
desc: Oscar winner Eddie Redmayne will play Newt Scamander in Harry Potter spin-off Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them Warner Bros confirms.

title: VIDEO: Sepp Blatter's controversial career
desc: Sepp Blatter says he will resign as president of football's governing body Fifa amid a corruption scandal - BBC Sport's Natalie Pirks looks back at the controversial career of football's 'Teflon man'.

title: VIDEO: State TV shows rescue of woman
desc: Footage has emerged showing the rescue of a woman after a cruise ship carrying more than 450 people capsized in a storm on the Yangtze River in China's southern Hubei province.

title: VIDEO: Teens injured in Alton Towers crash
desc: Four teenagers have been seriously injured on the Smiler rollercoaster at Alton Towers Staffordshire in an accident which also trapped all 16 people on board for hours.

title: VIDEO: Lion kills tourist through car window
desc: A female tourist has been killed in a lion attack at a game park in South Africa.

title: VIDEO: Nigeria bankers currency scam
desc: Officials from Nigeria's Central Bank are being taken court for fraud worth tens of millions of dollars.

title: VIDEO: Could this wi-fi doll give your data away?
desc: Rory Cellan-Jones examines whether connected toys or household objects like a wi-fi kettle could put your personal security at risk.

title: VIDEO: Zeppelin airship attack on London
desc: During World War ne a house in Stoke Newington was hit by a bomb from a German Zeppelin airship.

title: VIDEO: How to be 'Super Cool Biz' in Japan
desc: The government in Japan is encouraging a new approach to what people wear at work.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi: Where are you?
desc: Why has Aung San Suu Kyi been silent over the persecution of the Rohingya minority in Myanmar?

title: Odessa's new governor Saakashvili splits opinion
desc: The choice of Mikheil Saakashvili as Odessa governor in Ukraine is being seen as an unquestionably audacious move says David Stern in Kiev.

title: Two ways of coming to terms with tragedy
desc: Dresden and Nagasaki both have museums to devastating wartime bombing raids - but they adopt very different approaches says Stephen Evans.

title: Will the ECB play its ace over Greece?
desc: The European Central Bank has the ace of trumps when it comes to dealing with Greece's financial crisis. So would they play it?

title: Have we cured cancer?
desc: Immunotherapy is fast becoming a powerful new weapon against cancer. But is it the cure we've been waiting for?

title: VIDEO: Bad Weather grounds Solar Impulse
desc: A zero-fuel solar-powered plane's first attempt to fly around the world has been postponed due to bad weather. Peter Gibbs explains.

title: British tank crushes learner driver's car
desc: A German learner driver gets a tough lesson after pulling out in front of a Challenger 2 tank in Lippe Germany.

title: Caitlyn Jenner breaks Twitter record
desc: After gaining more than a million followers in four hours Caitlyn Jenner breaks a new Twitter world record.

title: Coke welcomes Blatter resignation
desc: Fifa sponsor Coke welcomes Sepp Blatter's decision to resign describing it as a positive step for football.

title: Ex-retail boss in restraining order
desc: The retailer American Apparel has been granted a restraining order against its former boss Dov Charney.

title: Egyptian repairman outranks Google
desc: An Egyptian repairman has managed to outrank Google but nobody seems to be sure how he has done it.

title: Lego game challenges Minecraft
desc: Danish toy company Lego launches a rival to popular video game Minecraft.

title: Manet Parisian painting up for sale
desc: An oil painting of a French barmaid considered one of the defining images of French impressionism is to be sold at auction later this month.

title: ITV 'should have made dog swap clear'
desc: ITV boss Peter Fincham admits Britain's Got Talent should have made things clearer over the use of a stunt double dog in the winning act.

title: Virgin-born sawfish found in Florida
desc: Seven sawfish in a Florida estuary become the first virgin-born vertebrates ever found in the wild in a sexually reproducing species.

title: 'Moon shot' call on clean energy
desc: Experts call for Global Apollo Programme to tackle climate change

title: S Korea has first two Mers deaths
desc: Two people die of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) in South Korea - the first fatalities from the disease officials say.

title: Canada tobacco firms to pay damages
desc: A Canadian court orders three tobacco companies to pay C$15.5bn (£8bn $12bn) - the largest award for damages in the country's history.

title: NZ thump England to draw series
desc: England slip to a crushing 199-run defeat in the second Test at Headingley and a 1-1 series draw with New Zealand.

title: Federer knocked out of French Open
desc: Roger Federer goes out of the French Open quarter-final while Jo-Wilfried Tsonga keeps French hopes of a home win alive.

title: Drips leaks and blocked drains in chic Paris
desc: Paris is a beautiful city but much of its housing stock is in poor condition notes Hugh Schofield himself the victim of a series of plumbing disasters.

title: Listening to the language of apes
desc: The similarities between apes and people have long fascinated scientists. Yet writes Mary Colwell the differences can be just as thrilling.

title: Bhutan breaks tree planting record
desc: A team of 100 volunteers in Bhutan sets a new world record by planting nearly 50000 trees in an hour.

title: Paris cuts 'love locks' from bridges
desc: Paris has started removing padlocks symbolically fastened to one of the French capital's main bridges by couples after part of the Pont des Arts collapsed last year.

title: J-Lo gig angers Moroccan MPs
desc: A concert by the pop star Jennifer Lopez in Morocco leads to calls for the country's communication minister to resign.

title: Japanese balloon art hits new heights
desc: Japanese artist Masayoshi Matsumoto has taken the art of twisting party balloons to new heights with his latest animal creations.

title: Russia says old missile downed MH17
desc: A Russian defence firm says an old Buk missile that it used to manufacture brought down Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine.

title: US labels Shining Path 'drug gang'
desc: Peru's Shining Path Maoist rebel group is designated a significant foreign narcotics trafficker by the US Treasury.

title: IS car bombs 'kill 45 Iraqi police'
desc: Three explosives-laden vehicles driven by Islamic State militants blow up beside a police base in Iraq killing 45 officers security sources say.

title: Quebec separatist Parizeau dies
desc: Jacques Parizeau the former Quebec premier who nearly led the French-speaking province to independence dies at the age of 84.

title: Four badly hurt in Alton Towers crash
desc: Four teenagers are seriously injured as two carriages crash on the Smiler rollercoaster at Alton Towers in Staffordshire.

title: Education 'antidote' to extremism
desc: Education is the most effective challenge to violent extremism said the incoming head of Oxford University.

title: MPs in line for £7000 pay rise
desc: MPs are set to receive a £7000 pay rise after the body responsible for setting their salaries says it intends to proceed with a 10% increase.

title: Marines march death trainee named
